sentences: Ema hoidis haiget last terve nädala toas
context: The Estonian verb 'hoidma' has multiple meanings including: 1) To physically hold or grasp something (like holding a map in your arm), 2) To keep someone or something in a certain place or condition (like keeping a sick child in a room for a week), 3) To look after, care for, or preserve something or someone. It can also mean to maintain something in good condition or to be careful with items and resources. The verb has various forms including 'hoian' (I hold/keep), 'hoiab' (he/she/it holds/keeps), and 'hoidsid' (you held/kept).
